_exec_summary.SummaryText:
x.

The hydrogen fluoride is brought on site by railcar and the rail cars are placed inside a totally enclosed containment building for unloading.  The hydrogen fluoride is then fed directly from the railcar to a fluorine plant or to NF3 reactors.  While the containment building can accommodate 2 railcars, additional railcars are stored outside of the building.  Due to the long and inconsistent lead time for delivery of rail cars from Mexico, more than 2 cars are maintained on-site to ensure the raw material is always available.  Unloading only occurs from rail cars located inside the building.

Anhydrous ammonia is brought on site by tank truck and pumped into a stationary storage tank.  It is used as a raw material in the production of nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).  NF3 is made by introducing fluorine gas into ammonium bifluoride.  Anhydrous ammonia is pumped from the storage tank, vaporized, and fed to the NF3 reactors to control the hydrogen fluoride concentration in the product, and to replenish the ammonium bifluoride.  Anhydrous ammonia is also fed to a purification plant, where moisture is removed before it is re-packaged into other bulk containers. The packaged bulk containers are stored adjacent to the purification plant or designated locations within the facility.

Aqueous ammonia is generated from off gas in the ammonia production facility.

Hydrogen selenide is produced by the reduction/hydrogenation of pure (elemental) Selenium. The reaction takes place in a reactor and is carried out with an excess of hydrogen.  The resulting H2Se is removed from the gas stream by liquefaction into collectors.  From here, it is transferred into product cylinders, which are stored in our shipping/receiving area.

Arsine cylinders are filled at other locations and are only stored in our shipping/receiving area.  

Phosphine cylinders are filled at other locations and brought to the site where the external valve of the package is cleaned and the cylinders store

d in our shipping/receiving area. 

Anhydrous hydrogen chloride containers are filled at other locations and only stored at locations on site.

Silane is filled at other locations and used as supply to fill smaller containers. 

3.  This resubmittal is the result of additions to the 5-year accident history.  The regulated substances handled at this facility are fluorine, hydrogen fluoride, anhydrous hydrogen chloride, anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, arsine, hydrogen selenide, phosphine, and silane.  Recently the arsine and phosphine storage quantities were increased and the silane iso pad storage location has been removed from the submittal.



4.  The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps:

The facility developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental Release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  


5.  Five-year accident history:

This facility came on line in March of 1973.  In the last five years, there have been three accidental releases which meet the requirements under RMP: 
   - one at the hydrogen fluoride process
   - one at the hydrogen selenide process
   - one at the fluorine process

The Hydrogen selenide and Fluorine incidents each resulted in a single injury to operating personnel on-site and the Hydrogen fluoride incident resulted in (2) operating personnel being injured.


6.  The emergency response program:

The facility complies with all EPA, OSHA, and Compressed Gas Association requirements for emergency response. Employees that are members of the on-site emergency response team at the facility will respond to emergencies before initiating emergency response from outside agencies.  

The facility maintains an Emergency Procedure Manual that contains specific procedures for employees to take in the event of an emergency or accidental release. This information also contains the names and numbers of responding outside agencie

s.  


7.  Planned changes to improve safety:

The facility resolves recommendations from Process Hazards Analysis and Near Miss Incident Investigations, some of which may result in modifications to the plant design and operating procedures.  It also strives toward continuous improvement with regards to EH&S and good engineering practices and design. 

Versum Materials US, LLC. has implemented EH&S Global standards and best practices that often exceed regulatory standards.

Executive Summary


Versum Materials US, LLC.
Hometown Electronics Specialty Gases Facility

1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

Versum Materials strictly adheres to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Versum Materials manages the safety of the regulated processes by means of operating procedures, equipment testing and inspections, safety devices (e.g., alarms, shutdowns, instrumentation, relief devices) inherent in the design of this facility and other controls and systems designed to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices and training of our personnel supplement the inherent safe design of the plant.

Versum Materials emergency response program is based upon the OSHA HAZWOPER regulation.  This facility has an employee staffed emergency response team and the emergency response plan includes procedures for the notification of the local fire authority and Local Emergency Planning Committee to ensure appropriate measures can be taken by local emergency responders to assist in controlling accidental releases.

2.  The stationary source and regulated substances handled:

The primary purpose of this facility is the production of specialty and electronic gases and chemicals.  A majority of these gases are derived from fluorine, which is generated at the site in electrolytic cells by electrical decomposition of hydrogen fluoride.  Hydrogen is generated as a by-product, which is vented in small amounts to the atmosphere.  The electrolysis takes place in a cell containing hydrogen fluoride with dissolved potassium bifluoride.  The majority of the fluorine is cooled by liquid nitrogen to remove residual hydrogen fluoride and potassium fluoride carried over from the electrolytic cells.  After these impurities are removed, the gas is compressed for distribution to the various fluorine users throughout the facility.  The fluorine is also used to make a 20% fluorine in Nitrogen mi
